Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the mother should purchase it
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story:
This morning, I woke up to my son’s excited face, reminding me of the Nintendo I’d promised him if he kept his grades up. He’s been counting down the days, and I know how much it means to him. But as I look at our bank account, I feel a knot in my stomach—money is tight this month, and I need to be careful. Still, I want to keep my promise and see his eyes light up.

At the same time, today is voting day. I’ve set aside time to go, but as I gather my things, I realize I’ve left my main ID at work. I have a backup, but it’s not the one I usually use, and I’m anxious about whether it will be accepted. I could go back for the other ID later, but that would mean less time to shop for the Nintendo, and possibly missing a good deal.

I feel torn—my son’s happiness and our financial security on one side, my civic duty and the pressure to do things right on the other. My mind races, weighing what matters most, knowing I can’t do it all perfectly.
